quoteFirst: There was at the corner of the Rue de Clichy a cabstand which she fixed as the boundary of her promenade. Each time she passed she noticed the clock on the cabstand. First it was twenty minutes to four, and more than twenty minutes to wait. Then it was
quoteLast: , and she had ten minutes to wait. Four o’clock struck. They were late. At twenty minutes past four neither Jacques nor Madam de Bonnivet had appeared.
title: The Blue Duchess
author: Bourget, Paul, 1852-1935; Tristan, Ernest [Translator]

quoteFirst: In about twenty minutes a generous rum issue was doled out. After drinking the rum, which tasted like varnish and sent a shudder through your frame, you wondered why they made you wait until the lifting of the barrage before going over. At
quoteLast: , word was passed down, "Ten minutes to go!" Ten minutes to live! We were shivering all over. My legs felt as if they were asleep. Then word was passed down: "First wave get on and near the scaling ladders.
title:
"Over the Top," by an American Soldier Who Went
Together with Tommy's Dictionary of the Trenches
author: Empey, Arthur Guy, 1883-1963

quoteFirst: The eye glances at the dial and sees that the minute hand has so many minutes to travel _before_ reaching the next hour. We accordingly say, for instance, it is twenty minutes to four or
quoteLast: . On one half of the dial we have acted quite scientifically in saying it is ten minutes past three or half-past three, but the moment the point of the half hour is reached we act in a different manner. We never speak or think of four thirty-five, four forty, or four fifty, unless we have to consult the railway time-table.
title: Chats on Old Clocks
author: Hayden, Arthur, 1868-1946

quoteFirst: Uhl, the second assistant, a man of some thirty years and ordinarily possessed of a disposition as placid as that of a little Jersey heifer, ordered one of his firemen to go and call the watch to relieve them. Mr. Reardon, his monkey wrench firmly grasped in his right hand, knew that at exactly
quoteLast: Mr. Uhl would issue that order--so he was on the spot to receive the fireman as the latter came leisurely up the greasy steel stairway. As the fellow emerged on deck he paused to wipe his heated brow with a sweat rag and draw in a welcome breath of cool fresh air.
title: Cappy Ricks Retires: But That Doesn't Keep Him from Coming Back Stronger Than Ever
author: Kyne, Peter B. (Peter Bernard), 1880-1957
